4.63.text:
Man, how am I going to follow that? (Laughter)
I booked him because I heard he was smart,

9.63.text:
but I heard he was a bit crap on stage (Laughter).
Dammit. Thank you, Aaron, that’s exceptionally

16.06.text:
kind and generous of you.
I said a little earlier today that, as MC,

22.37.text:
I’d be judged as much on my brevity as I
would my content, and I’m pretty sure that’s

26.37.text:
going to hold true for my closing remarks.
Seeing as I’m the last person between all

31.04.text:
of you and the riverside bar, I’m not going
to go on too long. I do want to say, though,

37.41.text:
I think today has been awesome – really,
really awesome.

41.30.text:
I’ve noticed over the last couple of years
that people don’t really care how much you

47.78.text:
know until they know how much you care. Today,
I think we’ve been pretty lucky to hear

54.21.text:
from a range of people who care a great deal
about public service and public services,

60.06.text:
people working both inside government with
us but also in the private sector. I’m thrilled

66.94.text:
and I’m personally humbled that I get to
be a part of that, so thank you to all of

71.25.text:
our speakers, and to those that were running
show-and-tell sessions, for your incredible

75.79.text:
contributions.
A year ago, Francis Maude stood on this stage

82.44.text:
and he said, “You’ve shown actually what
a civil service should be and can be at its

88.77.text:
best: skilled, innovative, challenging, disruptive.”
We want people who are challenging and want

99.41.text:
things to be different. I didn’t feel we
could mark today, in light of Francis’ decision

106.72.text:
to leave UKTI, without acknowledging and thanking
him for his vision, his support, and his leadership

114.43.text:
to create this special place that we now have
to transform government.

119.76.text:
I think that’s a good thing. I think it’s
actually a vital thing that we have so many

124.75.text:
people working together to transform government,
because we need it because, as you heard from

130.76.text:
the Minister of the Cabinet Office just this
morning, the ambition is great; expectations

137.17.text:
are high. As Francis’ successor, Matt Hancock,
said this morning, we are setting out to do

143.78.text:
nothing less than that: transforming the relationship
between citizens and the state.

153.45.text:
That is more than putting paper transactions
online, that is more than just trying to make

160.13.text:
the best of bad data; that is more than just
dealing with the worst of the legacy tech

166.95.text:
that we have. We – and I’m going to say
that a lot, and I want to be clear what I

171.68.text:
mean when I say, “We”: I mean everyone
in this room, I mean all of us, I mean we,

176.28.text:
government – we are going to transform the
relationship between citizens and the state.

181.95.text:
We’re going to do it by transforming government.
To do that we’re going to have to do a whole

191.61.text:
lot more, a whole lot more than we’ve ever
done before. We’re going to take government

194.71.text:
from its 19th-century structures, we’re
going to go beyond the limiting 20th-century

201.35.text:
technology that we have; we’re going to
go and meet the needs of the citizens in this

207.58.text:
century. No big deal, right? Here’s the
funny thing: I think we can do it.

219.16.text:
As everybody in this room knows, we have made
huge progress in just the last five years.

224.60.text:
We’ve designed services around user needs,
we’ve started working in new ways that we

229.41.text:
hadn’t considered before; we’ve asked
lots of questions about how we should do things

234.01.text:
and how we want to do things. We’ve been
more open and transparent with one another

238.90.text:
about what works, and we’ve been honest
and transparent with one another when things

243.79.text:
didn’t go the way we expected them to, because
we learnt to fail fast in the hope that that

248.38.text:
would help us succeed quicker. I don’t intend
to diminish the impact all of those things

254.87.text:
have, but I think there’s something else;
I think there’s something else that brought

259.19.text:
all of that together. I think what happened
in the last five years is we developed a collective

266.78.text:
will to transform. In doing so, we created
a shared responsibility for the things that

274.28.text:
we make.
It wouldn’t be an exec director end-of-sprint

280.59.text:
presentation if I didn’t mention Martha’s
report, so here’s my mention of Martha’s

285.02.text:
report. Her report in 2010 wasn’t the first
report to call for change; there were many

290.51.text:
that came before it. What it was, though,
I think, was the necessary push. It wasn’t

297.25.text:
a push to a specific solution or outcome;
I think it was the push that brought us together.

304.09.text:
It made us focus on shared goals, in a meaningful
way, for the first time. I think it’s that

311.46.text:
focus which is the most important thing that
comes next.

316.03.text:
Since 2010, because of that, we’ve been
moving at a pace that was unimaginable only

319.73.text:
a few years before. Now, because of it, we
have a real momentum behind us to make real

326.21.text:
change. We have the foundations in place to
really transform government together. Our

333.24.text:
collective will is the basis of that, and
it needs to be the collective basis for everything

338.11.text:
we do from here on out.
Just a couple of weeks ago – Janet, you

344.90.text:
are here, boom – just a couple of weeks
ago, GDS’ own Janet Hughes wrote about the

349.65.text:
need for boldness in the civil service. This
is what she said: “Being bold means bringing

355.00.text:
your whole self to the situation and engaging
fully with it. It involves openness, and optimism,

362.31.text:
and a commitment to something bigger than
yourself.” You were right, Janet. That boldness

370.58.text:
should be what we bring to work for the years
to come.

373.45.text:
We’re here to change things; that’s big.
We’re here to change things, and that’s

378.56.text:
exciting; we’re here to change things, and
that is a little bit scary. Sure, we need

383.02.text:
to be thinking about users and putting them
at the heart of our service design; sure,

386.78.text:
we need to be agile and be ready to respond
to things that we can’t even imagine yet.

391.87.text:
Beyond that, we need to be thinking about
whole services and not just digital transaction

396.25.text:
components and services. We need all of that,
but it will be for nothing unless we continue

401.03.text:
to be bold.
You know what? My experience: you’ve proved

407.55.text:
that you’re pretty good at it. You did that
– all of us; we, you did that: GOV.UK, the

418.60.text:
single domain of the UK government, an authoritative
voice on the Internet. It supports more than

424.90.text:
300 organisations; it saved £61m in the last
audited financial year. It’s had 2 billion

431.82.text:
visits; it’s had 6.8 billion page views
since October 2012 and is the 28th most popular

438.34.text:
website in the UK.
The idea behind GOV.UK is disarmingly attractive

445.93.text:
and, as you heard from Liam, has been copied
around the globe. GOV.UK is so easy to use

452.54.text:
that it fundamentally challenges the misleading
websites that have been ripping off consumers

457.07.text:
for a decade – and you built that. The idea
behind GOV.UK may seem simple, but only a

464.65.text:
few years ago it was a simple idea that seemed
impossible for us to deliver, and it wouldn’t

472.57.text:
have happened if we hadn’t worked together.
Indeed, it couldn’t have happened if we

478.17.text:
hadn’t been bold enough to try.
That’s not the only place you’ve been

484.62.text:
proving that you can be bold; DWP have been
leading the way on investing in digital academies,

489.75.text:
giving the skills – the digital skills – needed
by thousands of civil servants. It’s become

494.32.text:
the go-to home of digital skills development
in government, and other departments are either

499.50.text:
copying that model or beating a path to Kevin’s
door, asking where do they sign up? You’ve

505.18.text:
invested in digital skills for all civil servants.
We need digital not just be a bolt-on at the

511.11.text:
side, but we need it to be a part of the DNA
of the civil service. It was one of the top

515.51.text:
three priorities for the civil service in
the last Parliament, and it continues to be

518.89.text:
so in the next. We know that the best way
to learn is by doing and by recognising that

526.96.text:
you can’t do it all yourself. You shouldn’t
even try.

531.18.text:
Once again as to building on what Liam said,
the digital marketplace and the frameworks

537.33.text:
it supports has turned how we work into a
two-way dialogue with the market. You’ve

543.88.text:
heard you’ve put a billion quid's worth
of sales through the marketplace, getting

547.20.text:
government the skills and the services it
needs to do the job that it’s been tasked

551.01.text:
with, and that more than half of that has
actually gone to small and medium enterprises

555.20.text:
up and down the UK and Northern Ireland, disaggregating
the supply chain, distributing the work all

561.02.text:
across the country. As a result, government
is a better buyer; we are better buyers. It’s

568.28.text:
opened up opportunities in the market for
a wider range of suppliers than ever before.

573.19.text:
We’re buying smarter, and the market is
responding by providing smarter services for

579.10.text:
us to choose from.
You’ve also shown, by being bold, that you

585.00.text:
can take back control of our digital and technology
future. DVLA created a transformation capability

591.63.text:
made up of their own people – highly skilled
people – and allowed them to move away from

596.13.text:
a wholly outsourced, black-box services contract
that was disempowering them to control their

601.58.text:
destiny. Now they’re sharing the patterns
of how they did that with the rest of government,

607.20.text:
how they took back that control. That’s
important; they’re sharing what they’re

613.27.text:
learning and you have shared what you have
learned.

615.72.text:
We’ve talked about the digital service standard,
we’ve talked about the service design manual,

620.01.text:
we’ve talked about the technology code of
practice. This today, Sprint 16, the conversations

625.46.text:
you are having around the show-and-tells,
your blogs, your mailing lists, they are not

630.57.text:
the work of anyone personally. They are not
the work of any one agency or department;

634.96.text:
they’re what we’ve all learned. It’s
our better practice, not our best practice,

640.68.text:
because we know that when we’ve done a thing,
someone, somewhere, just found a better way

645.69.text:
of doing it and they’ll be open to sharing
it with us. That’s why our standards, and

650.39.text:
our guides, and our code of practice will
keep evolving. We’ll keep doing that alongside

656.45.text:
delivery; we will all continue to learn in
the open.

662.64.text:
It’s this last one for me, because being
bold is about acknowledging that we might

673.98.text:
not get it right the first time. Being bold
means not giving up when that happens. Not

681.48.text:
a single example I’ve talked about in the
last couple of minutes I think would claim

685.93.text:
to have been a success straight out of the
gate. That’s because success doesn’t come

690.62.text:
from avoiding making mistakes or trying to
find the perfect solution before you’ve

696.00.text:
even begun. Success comes from teams and individuals
who actively look to discover things, to experiment,

704.34.text:
to learn quickly what works and what doesn’t
work.

709.81.text:
Civil Claims is a great example of being open
to learning and to taking the hard call when

716.41.text:
you learn that the way you were going was
not the way that was going to be successful.

721.42.text:
Eliot Fineberg from the Ministry of Justice
Digital team has written about the optimism

725.95.text:
that often comes at the start of a new discovery
phase for a new service. It’s a time when

731.49.text:
you want to do everything and you want to
do it immediately.

735.52.text:
His post is a brilliant example of learning
in the open; if you haven’t read it, I strongly

739.10.text:
recommend you go read it, but what matters
here is that the MoJ team quickly realised

744.20.text:
that if they were going to do everything,
they would be locked in a cycle, a development

748.45.text:
cycle that would go on far, far, far too long.
We need to remind ourselves that services

754.32.text:
in development have no value. Services that
are live, services that are iterating, services

760.97.text:
that let users do the thing that they need
to do, those services have a lot of value.

765.98.text:
Get there quick.
In the end, the MoJ team changed their strategy

770.90.text:
to focus on a minimum valuable product, and
they released it early. That decision – it

776.79.text:
was a tough decision, they had difficult conversations
to get it agreed – that decision gave the

781.65.text:
team the space they needed and the confidence
they needed to develop better, simpler, more

787.61.text:
useful things, more valuable things for users.
In the words, in Eliot’s words – it’s

793.73.text:
on the blog – if he hadn’t done that,
then he wouldn’t have been able to say,

798.26.text:
“There’ll be many more good things to
come.”

800.03.text:
Bold behaviour, like Eliot’s and the Civil
Claims team, needs the right support. You

809.46.text:
need a centre that will back you up, that
will give you the tools that you need to do

814.15.text:
the right thing for your users. We’ve got
your back. I am proudest of the organisation

821.30.text:
that I happen to be fortunate enough to lead;
I am proudest when I see GDS fulfilling her

826.60.text:
roles as custodians of our shared platforms
and curator of our shared knowledge and practices,

833.36.text:
providing the resources that can support you
in delivery, supporting service transformation

839.37.text:
around user needs out in departments, and
agencies, and arm’s-length bodies. That’s

843.89.text:
what we’re here for.
Earlier I said, “Our standards, and our

849.36.text:
codes, and our patterns, and our manuals are
really just the names we give our collective

856.09.text:
better practice, our collective knowledge.”
We’re going to continue to support you with

861.76.text:
that; we’ll act on your behalf, as curators
and collectors of learning. We will be with

867.01.text:
you at the sharp end of delivery, and we will
work with you to find that knowledge, wherever

871.85.text:
the better practices exist, wherever they
are in our communities. We’ll continue to

876.16.text:
publish, and iterate, and evolve, to learn
in the open alongside you.

881.29.text:
We’ll work together to define new performance
measures that help us all understand how the

886.69.text:
whole service is doing, not just the digital
take-up or the cost per transaction, which

891.14.text:
is only a small part of success. We intend
to provide the expert support on things like

898.14.text:
digital strategy or service mapping, identifying
and applying service patterns when you need

903.77.text:
it, suitable at whatever stage you find yourself
in in your service transformation.

911.64.text:
Transforming services isn’t just something
digital teams or operational service teams

916.03.text:
have to do; it’s a shared responsibility,
but it is underpinned by skilled professionals,

922.37.text:
experts in their fields. That requires a civil
service that can attract, develop, and keep

928.22.text:
people who have the skills we need to transform
services. So, we are going to develop the

934.71.text:
digital data and technology professions to
do that, by simplifying the recruitment process

940.22.text:
to make joining government easier, defining
flexible career paths and structures, and

946.24.text:
developing cross-government reward and retention
strategies so that when we find good people

951.81.text:
they want to stay.
We will make the civil service a destination

956.89.text:
for people who want their skills to make a
real difference to society. We will make sure

963.14.text:
that this profession represents the people
we are building services for, by challenging

968.78.text:
ourselves to build a truly diverse and inclusive
workforce. All the while, we’ll continue

974.10.text:
to invest in working to develop a digital
DNA that crosses the entire civil service.

981.42.text:
Finally, GDS will remain at the centre, doing
the hard work on cross-government platforms

988.05.text:
and services. We won’t be building them
all. I’m going to say that again because

993.35.text:
I get asked it a lot. To be very clear: we’re
not going to be building them all in GDS;

999.57.text:
we are going to make sure they get built,
because these platforms and services will

1004.48.text:
make building, and iterating, and retiring
services easier for service managers.

1011.38.text:
Because of that, we’re going to keep leading
on shared platforms like GOV.UK, Verify, Pay,

1017.47.text:
Notify, Platform as a Service. We’re going
to continue to lead on common technology services

1023.16.text:
so that all civil servants have the kit they
need to do the job that’s required of them.

1027.72.text:
We’re going to continue to develop and extend
the marketplace so we have access to an even

1031.75.text:
wider range of skills and services and it
does the whole cycle, not just search but

1037.23.text:
purchase. We’re going to continue to invest
in civil service digital, which is building

1041.87.text:
the digital services that we need as civil
servants, not forgetting that we are users

1045.95.text:
too (Laughter).
We’ll focus on data as a vital shared asset

1051.67.text:
which underpins effective digital services,
and we’ll work across government to fix

1055.52.text:
how we manage, maintain, and use our data.
You’ve heard from Paul that we’re building

1061.50.text:
a linked ecosystem of canonical, properly
curated and updated registers of data. These

1067.64.text:
will be used to make services efficient, effective,
and, where appropriate, interconnected, designed

1073.14.text:
around users. To make that ecosystem work,
we’ll obviously need the right policies

1077.72.text:
and governance in place to make sure that
citizens’ data is secure and their privacy

1082.10.text:
is protected.
That sounds like a long list of stuff. That

1090.58.text:
is a long list of stuff. Everyone in the civil
service has a part to play in the transforming

1098.24.text:
of the relationship between citizen and state.
You’re all going to be leading on that.

1105.25.text:
I want to remind myself as much as anyone,
but everyone in this room, that leadership

1111.46.text:
isn’t a role; leadership isn’t a box on
a wall chart. Leadership is behaviour. We

1118.55.text:
are defined as leaders by the choices that
we make.

1123.65.text:
We’re all going to need to be bold to get
beyond the limitations of the past; we’re

1128.52.text:
going to have to put our reputations on the
line for what we know to be right and for

1132.19.text:
what we believe to be true. But we have to
trust one another in the knowledge that we

1136.15.text:
are all working to the best of our abilities,
be ready to challenge received wisdom when

1141.09.text:
we find it and admit when others have found
a better way of meeting user needs, knowing

1146.30.text:
that we are working towards a goal that is
bigger than ourselves.

1151.15.text:
The team I’m working on, they’re an absolutely
amazing team; they’re so passionate. You’ll

1158.25.text:
have seen that from the people you’ve talked
to. The passion is there and it’s all we’re

1162.23.text: focusing on just to get this thing live.

1164.65.text:
You want to make a difference. You’ve got
to be careful about that; how much difference

1168.76.text:
can you make being a small item in the bigger
puzzle? But a little project you may have

1174.40.text: there could touch millions of people.

1176.66.text:
It’s all about public service, delivering
things quickly, learning fast.

1180.84.text:
Redesign that service from the paid form,
to guidance, to the digital service. That’s

1184.25.text:
the challenge, is changing culture, changing
the way we work.

1187.44.text:
We are just scratching the surface of how
good we could be, building simplicity into

1191.21.text:
the services that people need to interact
with.

1193.01.text:
The staff, they can’t believe it: when they
raise an issue or a good idea, they can actually

1199.09.text:
see it being built and then released onto
live in such a short amount of time.

1202.67.text:
You feel like you’ve got the support there
to be digital, and to be agile, and to be

1206.47.text:
innovating all of the time, because you’re
not constrained by old processes.

1210.84.text:
People want to be connected; people want that
information.

1214.20.text:
The bar is going to be set really high and
we’re going to have to always deliver really

1219.10.text:
People are starting to see that the way we
do things, and this user research thing we

1220.92.text:
do and this user-centred design, is actually
better.

1221.92.text:
When you’ve got a team that believe in it,
then we get to do really good, thorough user

1226.37.text:
research so that we know that we’re building
the best things.

1229.71.text:
Working on policy in a digital environment,
you’re getting much better feedback. It’s

1234.44.text: quicker; it’s from the right people.

1236.95.text:
Everyone is fighting for the same thing; everyone
wants to do it properly.

1240.11.text:
The real important person is the person that’s
going to use this thing and making it easy

1244.23.text:
For me there’s only one way to really experience
it, and that’s to get on the ground and

1247.96.text:
I don’t think we’ll ever be done transforming
government; we just need to keep getting better

1277.59.text:
I said at the top it’s been a really awesome
day; it has truly. I said I wasn’t going

1280.96.text:
to hide my excitement and I hope I haven’t;
I’m more excited than ever. I have to thank

1285.71.text:
all of our speakers, all of the people that
were involved in the show-and-tells, and our

1290.39.text:
panels. Thank you to all of you.
I hope you started conversations today that

1294.23.text:
you’re going to carry on forward. In fact,
if you’d like to, there is an opportunity

1298.03.text:
now to carry that conversation on at the riverside
bar, which will be open as you head out. Please,

1303.14.text:
hand your lanyard back in; it will help the
team just keep everything going. There’s

1308.00.text:
one final thank you: Wendy Coello and team.
This is a thing that is pretty hard to put

1313.91.text:
together and I think it’s gone pretty well
(Applause). All that’s left to say is I’ll

1322.29.text: see you at Sprint 17. Be bold (Applause).
